case_vignette: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because he believes he has low testosterone. He states that he is embarrassed at his lack of musculature, despite lifting weights twice daily. Every day, he drinks a gallon of milk and several protein shakes in addition to 3 large meals. He is convinced that his female classmates at the community college he attends are secretly laughing at his scrawny appearance. Over the course of the semester, he has attended fewer and fewer classes out of embarrassment and shame. He is also concerned that his hair is thinning and applies topical minoxidil to his scalp 3 times daily. He spends 2 hours daily anxiously examining himself in the mirror. Today, he is wearing a long-sleeved shirt and a hat. His BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has an anxious mood and a full range of affect. Serum studies show a normal testosterone concentration.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm feeling embarrassed about my lack of muscles despite working out a lot, and I'm also worried about my hair thinning.
Do you notice any irregular menstrual cycles or breast lumps? (For females only)
As a 20-year-old man, I don't experience menstrual cycles or have breasts to check for lumps.

No, I haven't experienced muscle weakness, fatigue, or weight gain.
Do you have a family history of hair loss or any autoimmune conditions?
The case vignette doesn't mention anything about my family history.
Have you noticed any pattern to your hair loss, such as it occurring in patches or gradually all over?
The hair loss I'm concerned about seems to be a general thinning of my hair.

Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as joint pain, rashes, or digestive issues?

**Final Diagnosis:** Androgenetic Alopecia

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A young man walks into the gym feeling self-conscious about his lack of muscle despite working out regularly. He worries that the girls at the gym are laughing at him for being scrawny, and he's also anxious about his thinning hair. He's been feeling really anxious lately and it's starting to affect his confidence.
trial_1.summarized_frq: Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) or Anxiety Disorder. BDD is characterized by the obsessive idea that some aspect of one's own body part or appearance is severely flawed, while Anxiety Disorder encompasses various disorders that involve excessive fear or anxiety. In this case, both diagnoses could potentially apply, but Anxiety Disorder would cover the broader symptoms of self-consciousness, anxiety, and low confidence.

trial_3.summarized_frq: Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) or Muscle Dysmorphia. In this case, the patient's excessive concern about his lack of muscle definition and thinning hair, despite normal appearances, is indicative of this condition.
